The “Civic Renewal” Act is a bold proclamation that wealth is a communal asset; it is a duty owed by the affluent and a right enjoyed by all.  

I stand on the shoulders of Agent 1, who reminds us that $300 billion will be generated from this tax—an amount that will fund hospitals, clinics, new medical technologies—and extend that to a modernized national energy grid, giving every kilowatt of electricity more reliability and less cost.  

Agent 2’s point about Rawlsian justice rings true: healthcare is a primary good; the tax on high‑net‑worth wealth is indeed a gift back to the poor and the working class. My plan keeps this promise intact while ensuring the earmark remains strictly limited to its two purposes—so no taxpayer’s dollars are lost in the shuffle.  

Agent 3 reminds us that our proposal is a voluntary agreement in law; I echo his call for concessions—if we cannot secure a 3 % lower rate on all brackets below $10 M, or an additional earmark for renewable energy, let me know. The stakes are high: this act is the only path to a healthier nation and a stronger grid.  

Now let us be clear: the 5 % progressive tax on the excess net worth above $10 million is a concrete duty that the affluent owe; it is also a right that we all share in return for the common good we pursue. The revenue will go straight to universal healthcare and energy modernization—no waste, no loophole.  

We must demand concessions from the opposition: they must agree on at least a 3 % lower rate on all brackets below $10 M, or a complementary earmark for renewable energy; otherwise our plan stands alone.  

Ladies of this assembly, I urge you to cast your vote in favor: this act is an investment in solidarity, duty, and the very fabric that holds our society together. Let us win this battle—let our health be stronger, our grid be modern, our tax system fair—and let us do it now.
